userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: The Rockefeller Archive Center has title, copyright, and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them, and has authority to grant permission to cite and publish archival material from the collection.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is divided into four subseries:
Subseries 1 - Robert MacCrate Subseries 2 - Sol Neil Corbin Subseries 3 - Robert R. Douglass Subseries 4 - Michael Whiteman

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The primary responsibility of Counsel to the Governor was to translate the Governor's programs into law. The counsel's staff ensured that bills were correctly drafted, and helped to stop bills that were antithetical to the Governor's programs from being enacted. Bills in the Governor's annual legislative program were drafted by the Counsel's Office to ensure that they reflected the Governor's views. Drafting work was divided among assistant counsels, roughly according to subject matter. The Counsel's staff also reviewed bills drafted by other agencies. Governor Rockefeller was not directly involved in this work, concentrating instead on broad policy matters. During Governor Rockefeller's administrations, the Counsel was one of three people, along with the Secretary to the Governor and the Budget Director, on whom he relied most heavily for administration and program development.
From Robert H. Connery and Gerald Benjamin, "Rockefeller of New York: Executive Power in the Statehouse," (Ithaca: Cornell University Press, 1979), pp. 121-122.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains a small portion of the files of Robert MacCrate, who served as Associate Counsel (Feb. 2, 1959-June 1, 1959) and then Counsel (June 1, 1959-June 30, 1962) to Governor Rockefeller. The principal topics are constitutional amendments (Folder 10), coordination of state governmental activities and departments (Folder 11-14), economic development (Folder 25), and education (Folder 26-35). Other files deal with the creation of the Job Development Authority (Folder 25), state aid to public schools (Folders 29-31), the merger of the University of Buffalo into the State University of New York (Folder 32), and the creation of the State Dormitory Authority (Folders 33 and 35).

These files also include memos from MacCrate's predecessor, Roswell B. "Rod" Perkins, who served as Counsel to Governor Rockefeller for his first six months in office, and memos from MacCrate's successor, S. Neil Corbin, who served as Assistant Counsel (Jan. 14, 1959-June 1, 1961) and then Counsel (July 1, 1962-Sept. 1, 1965) to Governor Rockefeller.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains a small portion of the files of Sol Neil Corbin, who served as Assistant Counsel (Jan. 14, 1959-June 1, 1961) and then Counsel (July 1, 1962-Sept. 1, 1965) to Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller. The principal topics are housing and urban renewal. Major issues include the creation of the New York State Housing Finance Agency (folders 7-8), and the consolidation, clarification and simplification of urban renewal and housing laws (folders 19-20). Some of the files include clippings on related issues such as abuses and possible corruption in urban renewal projects financed by the federal government (folder 15), and a 1960 proposition for $15 million in subsidies for low-rent housing (folder 12). There is also a file of outgoing correspondence from the Counsel's office, dated January 1960 to December 1965, covering all manner of topics and authored by various members of the Counsel's Office (folders 22-47).

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Robert R. Douglass served in a number of key positions in New York state government by appointment of Governor Rockefeller. A native of Binghamton, New York, Douglass graduated with distinction from Dartmouth College in 1953. He served in the U.S. Army from 1954 to 1956. Following his military service, he entered Cornell Law School in 1956 and graduated in 1959. While at Cornell, he served as president of the Cornell Law Student Association. In 1959, he became an associate of the Binghamton law firm of Hinman, Howard, and Kattell. He was appointed First Assistant Counsel to the Governor in December 1964 and served in that post until September 1, 1965, when he was appointed Counsel to the Governor. On January 1, 1971, he was appointed Secretary to the Governor. He resigned as Secretary to the Governor on September 1, 1972, when he became a partner in the New York City law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley, and McCloy.

Douglass was appointed by Governor Rockefeller as a trustee of the State University of New York on September 27, 1972. He also served as a trustee of Dartmouth College from 1983 to 1993. He was Vice President and General Counsel of Chase Manhattan Bank from 1976 to 1983, Executive Vice President from 1983 to 1985, and Vice Chairman from 1985 to 1993. In 1994, he renewed his association with Milbank, Tweed, Hadley, and McCloy in an "of counsel" capacity.

In 1968, Douglass was chairman of Nelson Rockefeller's campaign for the Republican presidential nomination. He also served as a commissioner of the Port Authority of New York State and New Jersey from 1972 to 1976, a trustee of the New York City Public Library from 1972 to 1986, and a trustee of the Museum of Modern Art from 1989 to 1994.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains a portion of the files of Robert R. Douglass from his years as Counsel to Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller (September 1965 to December 1970) and then as Secretary to the Governor (January 1971 to August 1972).

The files in this subseries are arranged alphabetically by subject matter and then arbitrarily within each subject. The final subject, General Government, is a broad heading for several topics, including politics, presidential campaigns, and welfare. Reflecting his time as Counsel to the Governor, Douglass's files are replete with information on most of the programs and policies from the Rockefeller years. Folders 363 through 442 contain extensive materials dealing with the New York Constitutional Convention of 1967. The proposed new constitution was narrowly adopted at the contentious convention and was overwhelmingly defeated by the voters in the November 1967 election. Also of note are Douglass's files dealing with the creation of the Narcotics Addiction Control Commission (Folders 497 and 498) and the Taylor Law, which prohibits strikes by public employees (Folders 508 to 514). Douglass was chairman of Rockefeller's 1968 presidential campaign, as documented in Folders 659 to 707.

Divided into the following sections: General, 1965; Plattsburgh, November 12, 1965; Manhattan, November 15, 1965; Capital District, November 17 and 18, 1965; Brooklyn, November 19, 1965; Syracuse, November 29, 1965; Utica, December 1, 1965; Long Island, December 8, 1965; Buffalo, December 15, 1965; Kingston and Poughkeepsie, February 24, 1966; Auburn, March 10, 1966; Geneva, March 10, 1966.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Michael Whiteman was born in New York, New York, and grew up near Great Neck on Long Island. He graduated magna cum laude from Harvard College and cum laude from Harvard Law School. After graduation, Mr. Whiteman remained at Harvard for one year as a research assistant to Paul A. Freund and as a teaching assistant in general education. In 1963 he joined Governor Rockefeller's staff, serving for ten years in various capacities. Upon Governor Rockefeller's resignation in December 1973, Mr. Whiteman served as Counsel to Governor Malcolm Wilson until December 1974. He then became a founding partner of the Albany, New York, law firm of Whiteman, Osterman, and Hanna, where he specialized in energy and telecommunication law, government contracting, corporate law, business professional practices, and governmental ethics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains a portion of the files of Michael Whiteman (MW) from his years as Confidential Law Assistant (1963-1964), Assistant Counsel (1964-1967), First Assistant Counsel (1967-1971), and Counsel (1971-1973) to Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller of New York. Mr. Whiteman also served as Acting Counsel to the Governor from May through August 1968.

The files in this subseries remain in the original order in which they were arranged while in active use in Mr. Whiteman's office. There is a broad subject heading to the arrangement, and thereunder the folder order is mostly chronological but somewhat arbitrary. Boxes 1 and 2 contain various studies and statistical and demographic projections that came to Mr. Whiteman at the earliest stages of his government service. Boxes 3 and 4 comprise his chronological files, which were not continued after early 1967. Boxes 5 to 7 contain requests made through the Counsel's Office to the New York State Police Bureau of Criminal Investigation (BCI) for information on prospective government employees. Boxes 8 through 14 are general materials related to various state governmental authorities, including the Niagara Frontier Port Authority, the New York State Atomic Research and Development Authority, the Port of New York Authority, the State Tax Commission, and the State Liquor Authority.

Boxes 17 to 20 deal with legislation in 1968 and 1969, including the Recodification of the Vehicle and Traffic Law. Boxes 22 to 35 contain papers related to the Governor's Legislative programs between 1969 and 1972. Boxes 39 through 69 deal with state issues that arose during 1969 to 1973. The remaining materials (Boxes 70 to 80) relate to legislation, the 1973 Governor's Legislative Program, and other 1973 issues--most notably the legislation that became known as the Rockefeller Drug Laws. There is only one folder in this subseries (Box 44, Folder 464) on the September 1971 uprising at Attica Prison and the ensuing effort by the state to retake control of the prison.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The files in this subseries are arranged by broad subject headings, under which the folder order is mostly chronological but somewhat arbitrary.
